div.div: To zoom in on a specific portion of the spectrum, push two fingers away from each other.
To zoom out, pinch two fingers towards from each other.
To move along the x axis (energy) of the graph, place a finger on the chart and move it left or right to change the displayed energy.
Double-tap the spectrum where you would like to fit a peak.
Double-tapping again near an existing peak will fit for more peaks.

If you would like to force a set number of peaks in a region of interest: drag two horizontally aligned fingers over the region of interest. Remove your fingers and select the quantity of peaks you wish to identify.

Other Methods In the Menu→Tools→Peak Manager you can automatically fit for all the peaks in a spectrum using the button. It is recomended to have nuclide reference lines showing before using this automated peak search so peaks will automatically be associated with the nuclides responsible for creating the peak.

Launch Peak Editor If you want to re-fit, or manually adjust a peak, use the Peak Editor by holding your finger down on a peak for about a second, and menu will pop up to let you choose what you would like to do.

div.p: The easiest way to delete a peaks is to hold your finger down on it for about a second, and menu will pop where you can choose to delete the peak.

You can also place two fingers that span the energy range of peaks you want to delete, onto the screen, and move them up. Any peaks with centroids between your fingers will be completely removed; you can also reduce the energy range of peaks using this same gesture, as long as the peaks centroid doesnt fall between your fingers.
The Peak Manager (Menu→Tools→Peak Manager) and Peak Editor (hold finger on peak for one second, select Peak Editor) can also delete peaks.

message.center: From View menu select "Show Energy Slider".
message.div: This is an easy to use way to adjust spectrum energy range.
InterSpec will remember if you want the energy slider chart showing.

center.p: There are a number of ways to fit peaks, including:

ol.li: Double-Left-Click. You can double click near the same peak again to add another one.
From the "Peak Manager" tab click "Add" →. You can then adjust the parameters in the table to the values you would like.
From the "Peak Manager" tab click "Search for Peaks" to git all the peaks in the spcetrum.
Right-click on an existing peak and select "Add Peak" to add a peak to the same ROI.

message.p: Hint: before fitting a peak it is useful to be showing the reference lines of the nuclide responsible for it, so this way when the peak is fit for, it will get associated with that nuclide. This infomation is used to fit for energy calibration, detector response, activity, and shielding quantities.

message.div: To fit a definite number of peaks in a Region of Interest (ROI):
message.center: CTRL + Left-Click Drag → and then select how many peaks.

ol.li: Drag one side of the ROI past the other side.

message.center: CTRL + ALT + Left-Click Drag → Optional: Adjust Quantities → "Accept"
message.div: Note: if do this action again, like first on a high energy peak, then on a low energy peak (or vice versa), the dialog that pops up will give you the option to preserve both actions by adjusting both the offset and gain so this way both peaks will remain at the energies you drug them to.
message.p: The "Energy Calibration" tab also allows you to either manually adjust energy calibration coefficients, or fit for them using the nuclides associated with peaks.

center.div: Place mouse near the edge of Region of Interest (ROI) and drag.

message.div: Mouse must be within the y-range of the peak, and within 10 pixels of the edge of the ROI.

message.center: Scale the amplitude of background and/or secondary spectra relative to the foreground by selecting View → "Show Y-Axis Scalers".
message.p: To restore the background or secondary spectrum to being live-time normalized, click the "Normalize" button on the "Spectrum Files" tab.
InterSpec will remember if you want these sliders showing when there is a background or secondary spectrum, but menu items will be disabled if no background or secondary spectrum is loaded.

ol.li: SHIFT + ALT + Left-Click Drag → Optional: Adjust Quantities

messages.message:
Keyboard Shortcuts
Ctrl-1 through Ctrl-7: Switches to the tool tab 1-7 (i.e., "Spectrum Files", "Peak Manager", "Reference Photopeaks", etc. tabs), or if Tool Tabs are hidden, shows the corresponding tool window.
Ctrl-h: Shows the in-app Help.
Ctrl-i or F10: Activates the menu bar for keyboard browsing (InterSpec menu).
Ctrl-k: Clears all showing reference photopeak lines.
Ctrl-l: Switches spectrum y-axis between log and linear.
Ctrl-s: Saves the current application state.
Ctrl-e: Opens the Export spectrum file dialog.
Ctrl-z: Undo the last action.
Ctrl-Shift-z: Redo the last undone action.
Mouse Modifiers for Spectrum Interactions In addition to these short-cuts, you can click on the y-axis title to toggle log/linear scale; clicking on the x-axis title will show/hide the overview strip chart.
Double-click: Fits a peak in the foreground spectrum at the clicked location.
Alt + Double-click: Fits a peak in the background spectrum at the clicked location.
Shift + Double-click: Fits a peak in the secondary spectrum at the clicked location.
Shift + Left-drag: Delete peaks mode - removes peaks in the dragged energy range.
Alt + Shift + Left-drag: Count gammas mode - counts gamma rays in the dragged energy range.
Alt + Ctrl + Left-drag: Recalibration mode - recalibrates energy using the dragged range.
Command + Left-drag (Mac) or Alt + Left-drag (Windows): Drag vertically to zoom in/out on the y-axis.
Mouse Modifiers for Time-Chart Interactions Use the menu in upper-right corner of time chart to simplify interactions.
Click or drag: Selects samples for the foreground spectrum.
Alt + Click/drag or hold 'b' key: Selects samples for the background spectrum.
Meta + Click/drag or hold 's' key: Selects samples for the secondary spectrum.
Shift + Click/drag: Adds samples to the current selection.
Ctrl + Click/drag: Removes samples from the current selection.
